questions.text:
Match the following tissue macrophages with respective organs:


 


	
		
			
			1. Kupffer cells
			
			
			a) liver
			
		
		
			
			2. Dust cells
			
			
			b) spleen
			
		
		
			
			3. Hofbauer cells
			
			
			c) lung
			
		
		
			
			4. Littoral cells
			
			
			d) placenta
			
		
		
			
			5. Mesangial cells
			
			
			e) kidney
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) 1-a, 2-c, 3-d, 4-b, 5-e

Explanation:

 

Name of the macrophage

Tissue/ Organ

Microglia

Brain

Dust cells or Alveolar Macrophages

Lungs

Kuppffer cells

Liver

Littoral cells

Spleen

Mesangial cells

Kidney

questions.text: Which type of macrophages predominantly contributes to tissue repair and resolution of inflammation in patients with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease complicated by pneumonia?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) M2 macrophages

Explanation:

The predominant type of macrophages contributing to tissue repair and resolution of inflammation in this patient's lungs is M2 type of Macrophages, also known as Alternatively activated macrophages.

  • Macrophages are of two types based on their activation:

 

 

M1 activation

M2 activation

Also known as

“Classical macrophage activation.”

“Alternative macrophage activation.”

Stimulus for activation
  • Microbial products (e.g., endotoxin); TLRs (Toll-like receptor)
  • T cell-derived signals (e.g., IFN-γ),
  • Foreign substances (e.g., crystals).
  • IL-4
  • IL-13.

Releases

Reactive oxygen species (ROS), lysosomal enzymes, nitric oxide (NO) and Pro-inflammatory cytokines

  • TNF-α
  • IL-1; IL-12; IL-23

Anti-inflammatory cytokines

  • IL-10
  • TGF-β

Function

Microbicidal destroys pathogens and amplifies inflammation.

Terminates the inflammation and promotes tissue repair (fibrosis).

questions.text: Which of the following statements about granulomas is incorrect?

choices.text: Granuloma formation is a Type IV hypersensitivity reaction
Granuloma formation is a Type IV hypersensitivity reactionIFN gamma is an important cytokine involved in the process
CD8+ is the type of T lymphocytes involved in this process
Granuloma formation is a Type IV hypersensitivity reactionIFN gamma is an important cytokine involved in the processEpitheloid cells in granuloma are modified macrophages

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) CD8+ is the type of T lymphocytes involved in this process

Explanation: 

CD4 T cells are involved in the process, not CD8+

  • Granulomas (Type IV hypersensitivity reaction) typically involve CD4+ T lymphocytes, also known as helper T cells, rather than CD8+ T cells. (Option A ruled out)
  • CD4 T-helper 1 (Th1) cells help activate macrophages and other immune cells, release interferon-gamma (IFN-γ), and maintain granulomas. (Option B ruled out)
    • Epitheloid cells in granuloma are modified macrophages. ​​​​​​​(Option D ruled out)
  • CD8+ T cells are more commonly associated with cytotoxic responses against infected or abnormal cells rather than granuloma formation.

questions.text: Which sequence accurately identifies lymphocytes, epithelioid cells, Langhans giant cells, and caseous necrosis in the image given below?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) d, b, c, a

Explanation:

  • Epithelioid Cells (label "b"): Activated macrophages transform into epithelioid cells, resembling epithelial cells with pink granular cytoplasm and indistinct cell boundaries.
  • Lymphocytes (label "d"): These surround the clusters of epithelioid cells, forming a collar. They play a vital role (mainly T cells) in the immune response to antigens presented by the epithelioid cells.
  • Langhans Giant Cell (label "c"): These multinucleated giant cells are derived from the fusion of activated macrophages and are often found in the later stages of granuloma formation.
  • Caseous Necrosis (label "a"): In granulomas associated with certain infections like Mycobacterium tuberculosis, a central zone of caseous necrosis may form due to hypoxia and free radical-mediated injury, resulting in the characteristic cheesy appearance of the necrotic material.

questions.text:
A 40-year-old woman presents with a persistent dry cough, shortness of breath, and bilateral enlargement of the lymph nodes in her chest, incidentally detected on a routine chest X-ray given below. Physical examination reveals fine crackles in her lung bases. Pulmonary function tests show reduced lung volumes and a decreased diffusion capacity for carbon monoxide. Which type of granuloma is commonly associated with the histopathological findings in this patient?

 


{{caption_text}}
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Naked granuloma

Explanation:

The given clinical presentation suggests Sarcoidosis, a systemic granulomatous disorder characterized by non-caseating granulomas (naked granuloma) composed of epithelioid histiocytes and multinucleated giant cells without associated fibrosis or necrosis.

  • The characteristic histopathological feature of sarcoidosis is "Naked granuloma,” which refers to the “absence of lymphocytic collar.”
  • Giant cell inclusions like asteroid bodies and Schaumann bodies can be seen.
  • Sarcoidosis is a classic example of a non-infectious cause of granuloma formation.

Stellate granuloma (Option B)

  • Seen in Cat-scratch disease and lymphogranuloma venereum.

 

Eosinophilic granuloma (Option C): Seen in Langerhans cell histiocytosis (LCH) and Churg-Strauss syndrome.

Durck granuloma (Option D): Seen in cerebral malaria.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a physiological giant cell?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Langhans cells

Explanation:

Langhans' giant cells are multinucleated giant cells (pathological) formed by the fusion of macrophages. They are often seen in the granulomas formed in response to certain infections or foreign substances.

  • They are typically found associated with tuberculosis.
  • They are characterized by a horseshoe-shaped arrangement of nuclei within the cytoplasm

 

 

  • Osteoclast (Options A), Syncytiotrophoblast Options B), and Megakaryocytes (Options C) are physiological giant cells.

questions.text:
A 45-year-old male presents with a persistent subcutaneous nodule on his forearm. Biopsy reveals the presence of multinucleated giant cells within the lesion, as shown in the accompanying HPE image. Further analysis indicates a central zone of lipid-laden macrophages surrounded by a wreath-like arrangement of nuclei. Which type of giant cell is most likely to be observed in this scenario?


{{caption_text}}
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Touton giant cells

Explanation:

The multinucleated giant cells described in the scenario, with a central zone of lipid-laden macrophages surrounded by a wreath-like arrangement of nuclei, are characteristic of Touton giant cells.

 

Giant Cell Type

Description

Seen in

Touton Giant Cells (Option A)

 

Multinucleated giant cells with a central zone of lipid-laden Macrophages are surrounded by a wreath-like arrangement of nuclei.

Xanthogranuloma, xanthoma, fat necrosis

 

Reed-Sternberg Cells (Option B)

 

Large, binucleated or multinucleated cells with prominent nucleoli, often with an "owl's eye" appearance (pink nucleoli)

(RS cells- also seen in DLBCL, owl’s eye appearance- also seen in CMV infection)

 

Hodgkin lymphoma

Warthin-Finkeldey Giant Cells
(Option C)

 

Large, multinucleated cells with irregularly distributed nuclei and a foamy cytoplasm. May contain intranuclear and intracytoplasmic eosinophilic inclusions.

Measles (Rubeola) infection

Langhans Giant Cells 

 

Multinucleated giant cells with nuclei arranged peripherally in a horseshoe-like or semicircular pattern.

Tuberculosis, Sarcoidosis

Foreign Body Giant Cells

(Option D)

 

Large, multinucleated cells with multiple nuclei arranged haphazardly.

 

Foreign bodies in tissues like talc, sutures, or crystals

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman undergoes a routine elective surgery for the removal of a benign skin lesion on her forearm. The procedure involves making a small incision, excising the lesion, and closing the wound with sutures. Which of the following statements accurately describes wound healing by primary intention in this scenario?

choices.text: Myofibroblasts play a significant role in wound contraction.
The wound is associated with large tissue deficits.
The wound is expected to heal with minimal inflammatory response.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) The wound is expected to heal with minimal inflammatory response.

Explanation:

In this scenario, the wound is expected to heal with minimal inflammation, which is characteristic of healing by primary intention.

  • Primary Intention Healing: 

    • Occurs in clean, small surgical wounds

    • Minimal inflammatory response (Option D)

    • Edges approximated → minimal granulation tissue 

    • Fast epithelialization, minimal scarring

  • Secondary Intention Healing:

    • Large, open, dirty wounds (Option B ruled out)

    • Requires myocutaneous flaps or contraction (Option A ruled out)

    • Extensive granulation tissue formation (Option C ruled out)

    • Slower healing, more scarring

questions.text:
A 30-year-old man presents to the clinic with a raised scar on his chest. He reports that the scar has been gradually increasing in size since he had a minor injury in that area about a year ago. On examination, the scar extends beyond the original wound margins and appears firm and raised. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis for the scar on the patient's chest?


{{caption_text}}
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Keloid

Explanation:

The most likely diagnosis for a raised scar on the patient’s chest is Keloid, characterized by abnormal and excessive growth of scar tissue that grows beyond the boundaries of the original wound and does not regress.

  • Scar grows beyond the original wound → unlike hypertrophic scars

  • Firm, raised, pink or reddish

  • Common sites: Sternum, shoulders, upper back, earlobes

  • Cause: Minor or major injury, surgery, burns

  • Functional impact: Can impair mobility if near joints

  • Treatment: Intralesional injection of steroid (triamcenolone)

Hypertrophic scar (Option A): While hypertrophic scars are also raised, they typically remain within the boundaries of the original injury. They may regress over time and are less likely to recur after treatment compared to keloids.

 

Exuberant granulation tissue (Option C): Exuberant granulation tissue, also known as proud flesh, refers to excessive amounts of granulation tissue, which protrudes above the level of the surrounding skin and blocks reepithelialization.

 

Contracture(Option D): Contractures occur when scar tissue forms and tightens, leading to restricted movement of nearby joints or tissues. They typically occur in case of burns or deep wounds. Contractures may result in deformity and functional impairment.

questions.text: Which of the following cell types is classified as stable cells in terms of their proliferative capacity and turnover rate?

choices.text: Stratified squamous epithelia of the skin

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Endothelial cells in blood vessels

Explanation:

Endothelial cells in blood vessels are classified as stable cells in terms of their proliferative capacity and turnover rate.

  • Classification of cells based on the proliferative capacity and turnover rate:

 

Labile cells

Stable cells

Permanent cells
  • These cells are continuously being lost and replaced by maturation from tissue stem cells and by the proliferation of mature cells.
  • Labile cells include hematopoietic cells in the bone marrow and the majority of surface epithelia (Option B, C ruled out)

 
  • They are quiescent and have minimal proliferative activity from progenitor cells.
  • They divide only when required but limited regeneration compared to labile cells.
  • Stable cells constitute the parenchyma of most solid tissues (liver), endothelial cells (Option D), fibroblasts, and smooth muscle cells.
  
  • These cells are considered to be terminally differentiated and nonproliferative in postnatal life.
  • Permanent cells include Neurons (Option A ruled out) and cardiac and skeletal muscle cells.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man undergoes a minor surgical procedure to remove a small skin lesion from his forearm, and the wound is meticulously closed with sutures. Three days after the surgery, he comes to the OPD for review. Which event of the wound healing process is typically observed in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Replacement of neutrophils by macrophages

Explanation:

A 55-year-old man returns three days after a minor surgical removal of a skin lesion closed with sutures, and at this stage of wound healing, the typical event observed is the replacement of neutrophils by macrophages.

Events in wound healing:

 

DAY

EVENTS

DAY 0

Platelets and Fibrin form blood clots. (Option A ruled out)

DAY 1

Blood clot remains and recruitment of neutrophils (acute inflammation). (Option B ruled out)

DAY 2

Blood clots remain; neutrophils accumulate, followed by thin epithelial layer formation.

DAY 3

Chronic inflammation sets in, and macrophages replace neutrophils. (Option C)

Granulation tissue begins (blood vessel formation starts)

DAY 5
  • Maximum granulation tissue (Maximum neovascularization)
  • Collagen bridging starts (Option D ruled out)

DAY 21(3RD WEEK)

Maximum collagen deposition (Type I collagen.)

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding wound healing is true?

choices.text: The wound regains 20% of its normal strength by 1 week.
The wound regains 70-80% of its normal strength by 12 weeks.
The wound regains its original strength eventually.
The initial collagen formed in the process of wound healing is Type-1 collagen.

questions.solution:
Correct answer: B) The wound regains 70-80% of its normal strength by 12 weeks.

Explanation:

The wound regains 70-80% of its normal strength by 12 weeks.

Wound Healing

  • At the end of one week, the wound regains 10% of its original strength. (Option A ruled out)
  • The wound regains 70-80% of its normal strength by 12 weeks. (Option B)
  • The wound never reaches 100% of its original strength. (Option C ruled out)
  • The initial collagen formed in the process of wound healing is Type-III collagen. (Option D ruled out)
  • It is replaced by type-1 collagen (strong and has the highest tensile strength).
  • In the end, the ratio of type-1 to type-III collagen is 4:1.
